remixed_from.author: droftarts
remixed_from.title: Parametric pulley - lots of tooth profiles

description.text:
This uses an OpenBuilds C-beam and can be used both motorized or not.

I have this up on OpenBuilds website as well which has a nice BOM as part of the project : http://www.openbuilds.com/builds/openbuilds-c-beam-double-slider.3462/

I'm using a Nema17 motor (http://amzn.to/1skFnRO) with a 5:1 planetary Gearbox.

I added an parts to support geared steppers. The 8mm shaft is shorter then a standard nema17 so I had to offset the motor mount. With a 27:1 geared nema 17 motor (http://amzn.to/1Xpih7N) I can do vertical movements. The parts are :

Motor Plate for geared stepper.stl
herringbone gears for geared stepper.stl
Geared Nema17 Adapter.stl

The End Brackets use 2 608 bearings each (for a total of 4) (http://amzn.to/1TaW1z5) to support a 8mm shaft. I drilled a 3mm hole through the shaft for the herringbone gear & the gt2 pulley.

I'll be updating this in the coming days with a BOM...

Here's a sample video I did with the unit :

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lrwcWFf3E8w

and here's a brief overview :

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GkWPYcDjcFU

and lastly a lengthy build video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1Y7jwQNCfKA

In the video you'll see my pan & tilt head used : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1396552

I'm using a miniEngine to control the motion but any controller can be used.

OpenBuild parts
C-Beam : http://openbuildspartstore.com/c-beam-linear-rail/
C-Beam Double Wide Gantry Plate : http://openbuildspartstore.com/c-beam-gantry-plate-double-wide/
Mini V-Wheels : http://openbuildspartstore.com/delrin-mini-v-wheel-kit/

  • I'm using 8 wheels on the double wide gantry for the most stability... you might get away with 4 or 6...
    8 Low Profile Screws M5 - 25mm : http://openbuildspartstore.com/low-profile-screws-m5/
    1 V-Slot Gantry Set - universal : http://openbuildspartstore.com/v-slot-gantry-set/

Misc parts
4 608 bearings - http://amzn.to/1TaW1z5)
8mm shaft - I'm using 5/16 steel shaft from home depot
I drilled a 3mm hole through the shaft for the herringbone gear & the gt2 pulley.
gt2 belt - http://amzn.to/1X8UGIC
8 m5 bolts to secure the end plates to the c-beam - I used 25mm ones from http://openbuildspartstore.com/low-profile-screws-m5/
4 m3 45mm bolts for the belt tensioner - http://amzn.to/1R1A1Pq
4 m3 nuts - http://amzn.to/24R5OfD
4 m5 bolts to secure belt tensioner to the gantry plate - I think i'm using 8mm - http://openbuildspartstore.com/low-profile-screws-m5/
zip ties

I redesigned the belt tensioner and am not using this one, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1564560. It keeps the belt more inline keeping more teeth in the bite of the pulley while putting less force on all the parts...

If using the motor option :
1 Nema17 motor - http://amzn.to/1skFnRO) with a 5:1 planetary Gearbox.

  • if you use the gearbox check http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8460 for parts. I modified some of the parts to us bearings I had, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1562415
    2 m5 bolts to secure the motor mount to the end bracket : http://amzn.to/1TCC6TN
    2 m5 nutes - http://amzn.to/1TcePZr

Edit ::
I switch controllers to simplify the wiring to a Dynamic Perception NMX. Here's a demo video showing both horizontal & inclined use : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K0ec4FYKiSw

I weighed the slider with the pan & tilt head in at just under 10pounds. My camera weighs about 3 pounds... so this setup is capable of lifting 13 pounds fully vertical...

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

FolgerTech 2020 i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

30%

Notes:

printed all parts with PET-G...

comments.author: amats

comments.text: check the construction video... should show you what you need... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1Y7jwQNCfKA&feature=youtu.be
comments.author: amats

comments.text: I had just finished a recent slider project, using OpenBuilds C-Beam parts, and was curious about other slider designs.  I was surprised to see a build that was not unlike mine.  I like your creation...and accessories.  Great job.  I will be posting my build soon, and you will be able to see the different paths that I took.  Significantly, I have Dynamic Perception parts, Stage R Motion Control parts and NMX controller.  The controller is the single thing that allows simple control with a compact battery.  My motor is a DP 19:1 gear motor on one end on a quick release bracket, and a bracket that holds the NMX and an 8000 mAH battery on the other.  The motor wiring runs through the C-Beam. The other difference I see is that I inverted the C-Beam, and my bottom trolley is 3/8" Aluminum with 6 full size Xtreme wheels for a solid. base  My camera dolly fits inside the open C-Beam, and will actually support a Stage R Pan motor, an ARCA compatible L bracket with a tilt, and my Olympus OMD-eM1 mirrorless...with less than a 1/4" sag on the end of  the stroke.  I will get busy and make my post with details.   Paul
comments.author: mordachifu

comments.text: very cool I look forward to seeing your design... for this design I need a better way to attach the motor... something tool-less... maybe a cam like on the front wheel of a mtn bike...
comments.author: mordachifu

comments.text: Chris...thanks for the response.  I will post my build when it stops raining in Georgia, and you can see my solution to a snap in motor. I will probably post on OpenBuilds site since I have no 3D printed parts.  I smiled when I saw your Rotator.  I had the same idea, but since I don't have a 3D printer yet I would have formed the shell from Delrin, which can be tooled with fine finishes, an is pretty stiff.  You can get pre-cut aluminum disks on Ebay that would be perfect...8mm precision rods and a few 8mm id flanged bearings, along with your printed timing pulley would make a plenty stiff unit.
comments.author: buffcleb

comments.text: what part of Georgia... my sister-in-law lives on the coast...
comments.author: mordachifu

comments.text: I am in Marietta, just North of Atlanta.  No, I don't have a mill or CNC.  Let's see, my second career...I became a Master Carpenter, historic trim, stair builder, etc., so I've been a fabricator for years.  I use aluminum and sometimes Delrin, which are easily fabricated with good woodworking tools.  A chop saw, drill press and disk/belt sanding machine are all I need.  I can bang out a custom plate in 5 minutes, drill to specs and sand some nice round corners, and it's ready to use.  Remember, for now I am just doing one-off projects.  When I use Delrin, I always appreciate how finely it drills and machines.  The only odd tool/process I use is to put an mill end in my drill press to cut flat bottom countersinks so my 5mm screw heads are out of the way.    I worked on the video some last night...soon.

description.text:
Hi everyone,

I want to share a new design I made for a thumb in the Raptor Reloaded hand by e-NABLE. The new design allows gripping of very small objects and also bigger ones. The design was made as part of a project done in the Bio-medical Engineering Department at the Technion-IIT and in conjunction with Haifa 3D organization.

The design is completely compatible with the original design of the hand and only requires printing the two rather small parts I made and a regular thumb pin.

I uploaded different type of CAD files, sketches and SolidWorks files.
Feedback will be highly appreciated. I hope this helps!﻿

A link to a video explaining the design:
https://youtu.be/I0HwPox_eN4

A link to a video showing the new design in action:
https://youtu.be/DRHTY_f8afs

A link to a video showing the assembly:
https://youtu.be/eWczE35RCZk

Printer Brand:

CEL

Printer:

Robox

No

Yes

comments.text: Hi, the place where the tumb is attached to the palm looks quite different from the enable Raptor Reloaded model. Do you have an stl file for it? Regards
comments.author: dimopep

comments.text:
Hi,
The "thumb_extension.STL" should properly fit on the regular RR hand with a standard RR thumb pin.
The "thumb_proximal.STL" connects to the extension also using a regular RR thumb pin.
Finally, a regular RR digit connects to the proximal using a standard RR finger pin.
I hope this clarifies everything. Good luck.

title: Cherry 3D Printer Enhancement Kit (Especially for Nema 17 Upgrade)

description.text:
This is a upgrade for the Cherry 3D printer.
Especially when the printer is equipped with Nema 17 Motors (See my other things), the Z-Axis is shaking a lot.

This upgrade will stabilize the printer.

It is available for 8mm and 12mm rods.
8mm is the size, the printer is built with, but i had some 12mm lying around.

You will need some M3 screws and nuts and 3mm woodscrews.

description.text: These toothbrush attach with 3M Command hook adhesive strips so they won't damage walls. They fit the strip from 3M Decorating Clips very well. ( http://www.amazon.com/Command-17026-VP-Decorating-Clips-Strips/dp/B000M3YGHS/ ) The holder is a little bit narrow, so some toothbrushes are a tighter fit than I'd like. Revision 2 would widen the base oval about a half centimeter without opening the holder neck width so more brushes fit nicely. I was inspired by dezbot's toothbrush holder ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9056 ), but wanted a version that mounted via 3M Command strip instead of a screw. In particular, borrowed dezbot's clever lofting to retain the brushes without them falling out.
Printed on a Makerbot Thing-o-Matic

title: Geeky 8bit character Rubber Stamps
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I bring you the 3D printed, 8bit character, rubber stamps! With included 3D printed handle. These stamps are quite big at 55.7mmx55.7mm (2.2inx2.2in). We have designed the stamps in such a way that you can have one stamp handle and change the rubber stamp design to the one you like. Great for scrapbooking, letters, personal messages or just for fun!

Let me know in the comments section if you like the designs and want to see more stamps of different characters and or symbols. If you don’t want to print&sand and just want to buy the rubber stamps, I sell them in my etsy store. Give it a look if you’d like, and also see my other Items.

https://www.etsy.com/shop/3DCreationsPR

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

MendelMax1.5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10

Notes:

The rubber stamps are printed in flexible filament while the handle can be printed in pla. For the stamp I used Alchement - Flexible(TPU) and Hatchbox PLA. I use simplify3d so here’s a guide to printing the stamp handle and the rubber stamp:

rubber stamp:

For the rubber stamp I used 2 perimeters, 8 top and 5 bottom layers, 0.2 layer height, 20% infill, 250 extruder temp, 60 bed temp, no cooling fan and 30mm/s

stamp handle:

Your normal pla parameters should work with the handle portion. I printed it at 0.3 layer heigh, 5% infill and 2 perimeter shells.

For the stamp holder portion you will need some support material. In simplify30 I used 50% infill percentage with 4 dense support layers at 70% infill percentage. Also a 0.60mm Horizontal offset from part. With this the support material should be able to pop off, in simplify3d at least.

Rubber Stamp preparation

Rubber Stamp preparation:

In order for the stamp to work as a rubber stamp you will need to sand the top portion a little to make it coarse enough to hold the ink. Once the rubber stamp is printed, lay a sheet of sand paper on a flat surface and move the rubber stamp in circular motions until its sanded evenly. I use a 150 grit sand paper.

description.text:
Hey kids, it's super awesome learning time!

I found another use for the Rattle Wand Thing- Ditch the rings and it becomes a sight word wand! Students practice reading sight words (a.k.a. high-frequency words), numbers, letters, or any other relevant target skill thanks to this nifty little cylinder of PLA. The teacher simply calls out a word, number, or letter and students use their super cool wands to point to them.

Just print out a set of wands and the included pages (or make your own) and you've got an activity for centers ready in no time at all!

1x2x2 Rubik's cube
easy to solve!
This was printed at .3 mm layer height.

print two of the pin files and four cube files.
print the pins files flat part down
print the cube files with the pinhole down and with support
put a small nut in one of the pin grooves and glue it into one of the cube
let the glue dry and then assemble the rest
if you have troubles look at the pictures or post a comment.

If you want to print the lid you should split the object using Cura or Slic3r or any other programm and then scale the lid to about 102%.

I printed the Openscad settings which are default.

If you choose the textsize to small your slicing programm might not slice the text.

Have fun and let me know if there are improvements needed.

on the "old" Cura-version 15.04.5

You can just right click on the object an hit "Split object into parts"

On Repetier-Host select the "Gear-Symbol" next to the object click on "Split Object"

title: i3ext for 1.75 mm E3D v5 hot end

description.text:
This is i3ext by sgraber, which I modified for E3D v5 hot end and 1.75 mm filament. The normal J-Head mount does not work perfectly with E3D because the mount geometry is a little bit different. This one fits perfect.
Equipped with involute gear profile to provide a constant gear ratio during movement of the extruder gears. Straight cut gears do not provide such a feature.
BOM:
  • Nema 17 motor
  • E3D v5 hot end
  • 2x 625ZZ
  • 1x 608ZZ
  • Silicone hose or springs
  • About 50-60 mm long M5 rod
  • About 20 mm long M8 rod
  • M3 nuts and bolts
  • MK7 filament drive gear
  • Probably forgot something

• Print body, idler, and gears. I recommend ABS
  • Cut main shaft from 5 mm threaded rod or make a shaft from smooth rod using a die. Latter might produce better accuracy. Make a groove in the shaft for MK7 set screw
  • Put two M3 nuts into the top cavities Install, and then attach Nema 17 motor.
  • Assemble and install the main shaft. You need two 605ZZ bearings, MK7 drive gear, big gear and some M5 nuts.
  • Install small gear into the motor
  • Slip E3D hot end into it's groove, and fasten it with some M3 nuts and bolts
  • Assemble idler, you need short M8 rod and 608ZZ bearing
  • Install idler. I used some silicone hose to add tension, but you can also use stiff springs

description.text: This is a replacement keycap for the keyboard of a Thomson TO9 computer. It is only for the top row of the keyboard - the row with the numbers. comments.text:
The keycap can be printed, as you can see on the photo. It was printed by a commerical 3D-print-service provider.
But: Most 3D-Printers for home-use can't print models, which start in free air above the printing area. They need a support structure or a model, which starts on the printing area. So, in case of Home-3D-printers you are right, but generally the keycap can be printed.

This enclosure uses acrylic sheets to build an enclosure for the solidoodle 3. It would easily fit the SD 2.  
This is my first Thingi. I've published it before testing because 1)my printer isn't here yet and 2) I want to show a few people more knowledgeable than I my work.

Materials 0.08" thickness acrylic sheets
1/4" diameter X 1/16" deep Neodymium magnets
silicone sealant Printing Instructions print 12 x sideclipobject
print 4 x topbottomobject
print 2 x topclip
print each rear clip
print spool holder Assembly Sides should pressure fit onto sheets. Top
drill holes on acrylic sheets using parts as guide.
Drill hole in rear plate for filament
fix acrylic to partswith #4 screws
Seal with silicone and let cure.
Attach spool holder to rear clip.
Use 1" pvc for rod.

comments.text: I'm using these spool holders on my Solidoodle 3. It's a nice geometry, engineered for strength, and prints beautifully with zero support material. I had to file the bottom of the U a little bit to make the 1" pvc pipe that ships with the SD3 snap in place. Thanks for uploading!

title: Mk8 Extruder Upgrade Base with filament guide for flexible filament

description.text: For use with soft and flexible filament like TPE, PVA, and high-flex PLA. The additional material added to the base will help to constrain the filament so that it does not buckle and jam. With the modified base, I was able to get around 45 mm/sec with a filament that I previously could not extrude at all. I made this so that I can work with the existing hardware that I had for the whpthomas design. If you are starting from scratch, you might consider going with the official MBI variant: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53125
Just print this and replace  the whpthomas base with this modified version.

title: Snoot for Subtronic Pro160 underwater flash

description.text:
A colleague at work is a sports diver and I helped him print this snoot for the flash on his underwater camera. It fits on a Subtronic Pro160 flash, and helps focus the light on the object. He has used it in fresh- and salt water at 25 m depth and it helps produce really nice pictures.

It's printed in three parts; body, lid and focus pipe.The lid and pipe is then glued together with ABS glue or black ABS dissolved in acetone. We made it this way to make it print easier.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 - 0,4 mm

Infill:

+20%

Notes:

Print in black ABS. This is to keep the inside as dark as possible.

Put a brim on the snoot body to increase it's surface area if you have problems getting it to stick.

The geometry is simple so the choice of resolution It's just a matter of how quick and smooth you want it to print.

How to assemble:

The lid and light tube needs to be glued together.
On most printers the first layer will be slightly squished, so it's advisable to sand the edge of the lid's inner hole ligthly in order for the focus tube to fit through easier. Use a fine grit sandpaper. Be careful so you don't rip of any layers.
Apply ABS glue or black ABS dissolved in acetone with a small brush to the recessed surface on the inside of the lid and on the tube's brim. Press togther for a couple of minutes and let it set for a few hours. Also apply som glue/ acetone around the seams to provide additional addhesion.
Once the lid has cured it can be screwed onto the snoot body. Tie a piece of elastic coord through the holes at the end of the snoot. This is so that the snoot can easlily be removed and attached from the flash when underwater.

title: Xiaomi Yi anti vibration mount for racing quadcopters

description.text:
This is anti vibration 15 degree xiaomi yi camera mount for my quadcopter Goby 210
This can be used for zmr250, qav210 or other racing quadrocopters.
It is easy to assemble any quad. Just use 2 pieces of zip tie for the bottom plate and zip together with the upper plate of the frame.
I didn't try the camera with this mount yet so i don't know the performance of shock absorber balls. I used the balls that come to me with my Reptile 500 frame. You can use any kind of balls. Diameter of mount holes is 6mm. Weight of the mount is 15gr with velcro strap.

Note: I added V2 files. In the version 2, the camera is closer to center of gravity and there is more length between four rubber balls so camera doesn't shaking left & right on windy days.
Here is the test video of V2: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sYkyspiOw3Q

Note 2: I added V3 file (top plate). I added support to back side of the seat so when you drop your drone, it is hard to break back side.

Fill: 40

title: Audi B5 S4 and A4 52mm Vent Pod Community Project Ver 0.2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a vent gauge pod designed to work in place of the driver side dash defrost vent on the Audi B5 A4 and S4 models. This is intended to be a work in progress and to be a community project to help engage B5 owners to start creating and sharing new and fun designs with one another.

Version 0.2 Notes:
-The side friction pads should be widened or increased in frequency to offer a more secure hold for added rigidity. This change is expected to happen in the next version (or by other users)

-The pod is currently two pieces to remove the need for supports during printing. It presently needs to be attached with adhesive or melted together with a soldering iron (shown). Future versions will hopefully have a slip fit connection to continue the "no supports" design

-I have included the original design files to help others get started with making their own variations (dual pod is as easy as copy, merging, and extruding a hole in the pod file). This is intended to be used, modified, updated, improved upon, and shared in a NON-COMMERCIAL manner.

-Pod is slightly oversized but uses "friction dots" to accommodate larger variations in 52mm gauge diameter discrepancies, and not require forceful insertion or the gauge becoming "stuck". Couldn't find my spare Podi Gauge to test with so some minor alterations mat still be needed

-Dual Pod is untested for clearance of cluster hump, may require adjustment.

I hope this encourages others to build and grow items for the B5S4 community and share them freely.

-Pod Angle may need to be adjusted per individual taste.

EDIT:

Two additional files [DriverDashVentBLANK.123dx & DriverSideVentBLANKSTL.stl] have been added. These are slightly different from the vent vases used in the pods and have not yet been tested. These contain no additional "friction dots" but is only intended to give individuals a blank slate to start building their own designs from without having to "undo" things that were required for the pod stalk to be added. Hopefully this makes it easier for people to get started building!

Keep building, creating, and sharing!!!!

Printer:

Printrbot Simple

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Notes:

Printer: Printrbot Simple (First Version)

Quality could be much improved with a finer calibrated machine or just a nicer machine in general, but not shabby for a $200 printer using wood and zipties lol

Material: PLA (ABS would likely be better as it will sit in the sun a lot)
200c temp
0.3 resolution

Pod Print: ~2 hours
Vent Print ~ 1 hour

Your mileage may vary

description.text:
This is the badge the Hack a Day team wore around CES and gave away to a few people. You can see the posts here:
http://hackaday.com/2010/01/08/ces-update-makerbot-gets-a-badge/
and here:
http://hackaday.com/2010/01/09/ces-update-ces-badges/ Here is the how-to post on how the badge was created in OpenSCAD:
http://hackaday.com/2010/01/11/how-to-make-a-printable-ces-badge/ Now everyone can show that they read hackaday.com with this custom-designed badge.
It takes a little over an hour to print and the wrenches are pretty much guaranteed to pull up and/or warp the build surface.

1: Download the stl file.
2: Skeinforge said stl file.
3: The stl is not centered in the y direction so you will need to setup the build platform about 1cm towards the back from the center of the build platform if you have a Cupcake CNC.
4: This build has a huge initial surface area and will attempt to foil its own creation by pulling up. You will need to recite incantations, sacrifice dust bunnies in a fiery cauldron of acetone, whatever it takes, just don't get mad at your machine when your print starts to pull up.
5: Remove from the build platform and raft.
6: Attach a bar pin to the back with hot glue or epoxy.
7: Allow glue to cool/cure/dry.
8: Proudly wear upon your getup to show you read Hack a Day!

author: Devlin

description.text:
This is a tubular drive mechanism. It is designed to use 1/2 inch aluminum conduit. This is a work in process, and I am already working on a newer version that will use dual rails. I think that this type of mechanism will work well as an linear axis drive mechanism when combined a stepper motor, and magnetic linear encoder would provide high accuracy large scale positioning. Tubular Drive Test Fixed Drive
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k0G8B77UOJs Tubular Drive Test Fixed Conduit
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=70dTRN7zSpU

Print the parts with 75% infill 3 shells. Print the spacers at 100% infill.
This uses standard 608 skateboard bearings for the wheels. Brush the sides of the wheels with acetone and sandwich the bearing between them. After the wheel has setup and is hard brush the surface of the wheel with acetone, this will help to bond the abs even more.

comments.text: This could be good printable alternative to linear bearings, even with traditional belt-driven movements. As far as driving is concerned, I suspect there wouldn't be enough friction to reliably position printing surface due to slipping. On the other hand, if you build reliable absolute positioning sensor with magnetic strip or just current sensor, if could be mitigated, but it would require firmware changes.
comments.author: IgorLobanov

comments.text: The friction is pretty high, more then I would have thought.  The drive has bolts so you can increase the wheel pressure.   As soon as my stepper motor arrives I will do some testing to determine accuracy.  I also ordered a linear encoder, so I should be  able to do some step corrections.  I will have to look at what changes I will need to make to the drive code.
comments.author: IgorLobanov

comments.text: Did you do anything to the curved surface of the drive roller to smooth it down or make it more accurate?   I tried something similer to this and could never get it to roll smooth enought on the shaft due to runout and imperfections in the printed surface.

comments.text: I brushed it with acetone, this helped to bond the printed abs.  After the surface was dry to the touch but still soft I rolled it back and forth on the conduit.  This rolls extremely smoothly.

comments.text: I think it work well in a gantry type application.  You can stiffen aluminum conduit by inserting oak dowels the inside diameter of the conduit to achieve long runs. My stepper motor version will use the Makerbot stepper driver connected to an Android ADK.

print_settings.Notes:: A great addition to the Flashforge Creator 2, imho.

description.text:
I thought the stock top plate tube holder was lacking so I designed what I consider an improvement.

It is the same thickness, that part was fine. I added some sleeves to help secure and support the two feeder tubes. I also added a split 2" long sleeve for all the wiring to feel into with two indentations for tie wraps. Another thing you can do is remove the horrid spiral wrap from the cable and replace it with 1" Grip Wrap Sleeving, http://www.cabletiesandmore.com/grip-wrap.php. It is the woven sleeving that the Makerbot Replicator has but is velcro like and has adjustable diameter. You can wrap your harness with it, overlapping the split sleeve and tie wrap it.

title: Rugged camera case for Panasonic Lumix DMC-TS30

description.text:
3D printed rugged camera case for Panasonic Lumix DMC-TS30

The camera is already:

  • Water Proof
  • Shock Proof
  • Freeze Proofe
  • Dust Proof

But the deal is that it is too small and hard to operate with gloves or in movement, the surface is too "smooth"; it may be Shock proof but I still don't want to drop it.

The case allows the camera to be fully operated and cover all the sides, it has a pattern surfaces to better handgrip and protects the screen.

I actually stood over the case and then on top of the camera with the case, I think I made it almost indestructible ...almost.

title: Cooling Duct - Fits Qidi Tech (and likely others)

description.text:
This cooling duct works with the stock turbo fan that is included with the Qidi Tech printer (mine is an early 2016 model). The included duct was inadequate in getting quality results from various test prints (like Marvins, CtrlV, etc.), so I designed my own. I was working towards a duct that split off and routed air to both extruders, but had mixed results. I'll get back to that at some point, but for now I have this version that is for the left extruder only. I get high quality results with PLA using this duct.

Using the duct that came with your printer, you shouldn't have to use supports for this print. Print both parts, then use a little bit of super glue to attach the input to the rest of the duct.

description.text:
This is my remix of a great design I found on Thingiverse. I made minor modifications to accommodate my dial indicator which has a 20mm wide mount tab instead of an 18mm mount. If your mount tab is 18mm wide, use the original design. I was surprised by how much my bed was off after checking it with this tool. This tool is designed for Prusa printers with Z axis bearing rods 45mm apart. It fits perfectly on my printer. The dial indicator does a far more precise job of leveling the bed than using the drag paper method. I have found that my first layer is much more consistent. It is especially helpful for larger prints. It is also quicker to check the four corners with the dial indicator than using paper because I don't have to bring x axis near the bed. I can just zero the dial indicator on one corner and adjust the other three corners to match.

My procedure:

  1. Attach the dial indicator to left side of X axis and move the bed forward so that indicator is in rear corner. Zero the indicator.
  2. Move the bed backwards and take reading on the front left corner. Adjust the bed leveling screw until the dial indicator reads zero.
  3. Move dial indicator to right side of X axis carriage being careful not to zero it. Take a reading on front right side of bed and adjust the bed leveling screw until the indicator reads zero.
  4. Move the bed forwards and take reading on the rear right corner. Adjust the bed leveling screw until the dial indicator reads zero.
  5. Move the extruder to the middle of the bed and do you normal Z height adjustment. All four corners are level so no check should be needed other than the middle of the bed

A comfy place to rest your head after a hard day in space.  1:18 scale.
I have made some small design adjustments since printing the prototype shown on this page, reducing height by about 8mm and improving stack-ability.

Some things to consider:
The Shell & Trim require 120mm build area.  If you're using a 120mm platform, make sure it's perfectly centered and well leveled. I do plan to provide a file split up for a 100mm platform soon.
The Base is optional.  Pods are built to stack with and without bases, bunk bed style.  
The seat is formatted so that the bottom cushion prints upside down.
Printed with basic Print-o-Matic settings on a ToM.  20% infill, no extra shells.
Assemble as per photo.  Or, mix it up.  The base and cushion would make a nice futon, in the event your extra stellar environment suffers from space constraints.  Or, go low-rent with a cushion-less sleep pod for that sci fi look without all the effort.

This is a 4-relay module box for use with ezHomeAutomation project (http://ezhome.cjz.com.br). The project is under construction.

The cover can be fitted without the need for screws. The socket-screw can be used for fixation.

Probably far from the most efficient way to get the 2D drawings, but during my experimentation with making my Menger Sponges I decided to see how deep I could get with the simpler geometry of a Sierpinski carpet. I got up to 5 on a single Solidworks part, but had to export that and reimport/tile the parasolid to reach 6. As you can see in the images I used a lasercutter on some birch squares (about 1/8" thick) to cut out the level 5.

I included the STL exports as well because why not. If you want an STL that's thicker (I arbitrarily made the parts .125" thick) or something and can't do it yourself I can tweak the parts pretty easily (except the level 6, that'd be a little tricky, but I could try). Haven't used the STLs for anything myself.

print_settings.Notes:: Don't forget to rotate parts before printing

description.text:
New version of the Round Tower with customizable modular floor.
Go in the customizer to make your own tower part.

You can choose the type of tower part than you want to create :

  • Template 'Ground'
  • Template 'Floor'

You can stack on the template 'Ground' one or more template 'Floor'.

For the template 'Ground' :

You can choose between 4 different styles of gate :

  • Angular arch
  • Roman arch
  • Pointed arch
  • Ogee arch

You can choose the heigth, the width and the position of the gate(s) [max 4, front, back, left and right].

You can choose the heigth and the width who will be the same for the 4 battlements (or low part of windows, if you stack a template 'Floor' over this template).

For the template 'Floor' :

No gate here, but the high part of windows.
You can choose between 4 different styles of window :

  • Angular arch
  • Roman arch
  • Pointed arch
  • Ogee arch

You can choose the heigth and the width who will be the same for the 4 windows.

You can choose the heigth and the width who will be the same for the 4 battlements (or low part of windows, if you stack a template 'Floor' over this template).

Second version, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1548065

description.text:
A set of numbers and rails to build a nice, durable number sign for your mailbox. You can combine the numbers side to side to print a single plaque if you wish. After you print your numbers measure the total width and print a top rail to the exact width and a bottom rail to the width plus 1/2" (12.7mm). The Rail Caps fit over the longer bottom rail and have holes for easy mounting. After assembly I used a piece of ultra bright plastic coated reflective tape on the backside. Now the numbers jump out at you at night, my previous mailbox numbers had a sprayed on reflective coating that had grown dim over time.

Added a 'Flush Mount Cap' for mounting on the side of the mailbox or wall. Print two top rails 1/2" (12.7mm) longer than the total width of the numbers and two Flush Mount Caps for the set.

EDIT 05/16: Updated Rail Cap so each end has the proper geometry.

title: Zebralight H600w Mk II helmet Gopro mount / bracket

description.text:
This is a Gopro mount for Zebralight H600w Mk II headlight (possibly fits Nitecore HC30 and similar).

I have designed this to accommodate 2 headlights on standard helmet Gopro mount but it can also take single flashlight.

Total weight:

  • approx 270g with 2x Zebralight H600w Mk II (2000lm in boost mode!)
  • approx 150g with 1x Zebralight H600w MkII (1000lm in boost mode)

Design is slightly bulky but it's really easy to print.
Would probably look better in black but I've just run out of black filament.

Print on a flat side with or without supports with ABS (or stronger filament) at 0.2mm resolution and 20-30% infill.
Use 4x Size #8 40mm+ long flat head screw with hex nuts.

author: squbel

description.text: By request, here's an adapter for plugging some sort of ipod into some sort of pip-boy. And here's how to design your own!

Step 1

Go to http://www.freecadweb.org/wiki/?title=Download and click the appropriate link for your operating system. I like the dev release and have found it totes stable, but if you want to play it safe you can use the Stable Installers. If you're running Windows you'll have to know whether your OS is 64 bit or not, you can get that from Control Panel -> System or right-clicking the background of the "Computer" window and hitting Properties.

Step 2

If you're replicating a physical thing, measure it with calipers (several pair are printable from this very site if you don't have them lying around); FreeCAD defaults to mm, that seems to be pretty common in the community.

In my case, these were all provided by dajcarrol, so - get your numbers however you get your numbers.

The New File icon Step 3 - load FreeCAD and start a new file

See the icon above - and make sure you're in the Part Design workbench. Or, if yours starts in the Start workbench:

The New Sketch icon Step 4 - make a new sketch

Click the icon for a new sketch

The Choose Orientation dialog

the Choose Orientation Dialog pops up. Here's an excellent opportunity to think over how we want to print the finished product - face up? Face down? Sideways? Diagonally?
It doesn't matter much if you get it wrong - you can always reorient it in slic3r. I chose the default, top-down view.

The sketcher toolbar Step 5 - First Rectangle

Click the rectangle button (above) and click-and-drag a rectangle vaguely around the origin - it doesn't have to be perfect, we'll dial it in soon.

Now click two of the red horizontal endpoints and the vertical green line - they should all turn green

now find the "Center" constraint icon - it looks like a red "> <". This centers the horizontal line relative to the vertical origin axis, which just makes things tidy.

Mine is vertical, yours may be horizontal

Do the same thing with two vertical endpoints and the pink horizontal axis:

Now select one of the vertical lines

thusly

and hit the Vertical Constraint icon (pictured, looks like an upper-case serif i)

When the dialog pops up, plug in the measurement. Then select a horizontal and hit the "H" shaped Horizontal Constraint icon, and plug in the measurement.

Fully Constrained is good - you've given it all the measurements. Step 6 - Padding that rectangle

Click either the Close button from the previous image, or the Close Sketch icon on the same toolbar from which you created the sketch

Then click the yellow block icon next to it that just lit up to pad it:

in the menu, set the height of the pad - in our case, 3mm. We don't need anything fancy this time around.

Step 7 - pocketting a hole in that pad

select a face of the resulting solid - it's hard to tell, but it gets marginally lighter.

Now hit the trusty New Sketch button - FreeCAD will automatically put This sketch on the face you just selected.

Just like last time, make and center a rectangle, plugging in its dimensions. We're lucky it's centered, but as we'll see later, it's no big deal to run it offset from the first rectangle.

Close it and hit the Pocket icon, right next to the Pad icon. To do this properly we should tell it to go through all or to a face (and then carefully select the face on the opposite side) - but telling it to cut out 5mm worth of a 3mm thick surface is good enough.

just might give us trouble were we to later adjust the thickness Step 8 - adding legs

Click the face of the object again, create a new sketch again, and this time - we'll bring in eXternal Geometry. (You can use the X key to enter this mode, or click the icon, whatever you're comfortable with)

For this I selected all 4 outside edges - you can do it with just the top and bottom too, but that has its own problems with constraining the corners.

Now add a rectangle - Important, hover over the top-left corner until a red dot appears by the cursor (that means FreeCAD recognizes you're trying to make them share a point). Then drag to the right-side purple line, and hover until the Point-On-Surface icon appears (sort of a dot on a 90° arc, pictured) - that means it knows you want it to stop on that line.

Same thing on the bottom, but you may have noticed - now it's bloody impossible to select the edges of those rectangles!
I know! And there's no way to tell FreeCAD to put the purple lines /under/ the new lines, or make them thinner, or dotted, not that I've found...but all is not lost.
Go all the way to the left and scroll down until you see the Elements.

Click through the lines until one you like lights up - the last 4 will be the eXternal Geometry, but the 8 before that will be the ones we just added.

Add vertical constraints as normal; all the lines should turn green for a fully-constrained sketch.

Close out of the sketch as normal and pad it up like we did the first one; I padded 12mm, +3mm for the original surface=15mm total (I think I did anyway, won't it be fun to find out?)

Step 9 - Save your STL

You've been saving the FreeCAD file all along, right? Bah, doesn't matter. Save works the same as anywhere, but Export is what we're after. Make sure you select the pad:

The grayed out ones are earlier editions - you can return to them as a sort of eternal Undo buffer if it ever comes up.

Then go to Export

and make sure you set the filetype to STL Mesh:

And you're done! Some Thingiverse denizens prefer STEP files, but Thingiverse itself insists on STL. For best results run it through Slic3r (easy enough to google) to check for missing or impossible geometry; I don't understand how it works, so, good luck!

The Samsung Gear Live smart watch charging cradle has a small plastic clip to hold it in place that is easy to break off. As the watch is no longer manufactured finding a replacement cradle can be difficult. This thing is a simple clip that will hold the broken cradle in place while charging - I've been using mine for over a week now without problems.

I've included the OpenSCAD source file for generating the model as well as an STL file repaired with NetFABB.

title: Killer Key for Kwikset Locks Kills Locks Dead
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Killer Key will permanently disable a Kwikset lock. You can only insert this key once and it will lock in place and permanently RUIN/DESTROY your Kwikset door lock. Once the key is inserted any attempt to remove it will break the head off.

The way this key works is that it latches onto a tumbler inside the lock cylinder making it impossible to turn the lock or remove the key.

WARNING!!!! A single use of this key will permanently destroy your Kwikset lock.

You can buy these on Amazon for about $12 so I thought a plastic version would be just as effective.

I am not responsible for your use of this key.
Print and destroy a lock or two.

description.text:
**Update: 5/30/16 First flight, I landed hard (not used to the added weight...) and both flanges and one Tee cracked at the joint. Be sure to use more than 3 shells and 20% fill. I'll go back and see if I can beef up the fillets at the joints as well.

I decided to add a gimbal and camera system to my F450 quadcopter clone and needed a set of landing gear to raise the quad up to clear the camera. I bought a retractable set from HK that didn't work. So while I waited for the replacement I made this set so I could install the camera and get it set up. I like it so much, I might not put the retractable set on!.....

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in PLA with 3 shells and 20% infill to make them sturdy.

I designed these in Autodesk 123D Design. I used 1/2 in. square basswood stock for the main down supports. They are 7 inches long, though once I mount the gimbal and camera I might go back and reduce their length a bit to lower the center of gravity and still clear the camera. I used 3/8 in. basswood for the feet. The feet fit very tight in the Tees and Caps, but the main supports were a tad loose for my liking so I drilled and attached single screws at each connection. You could glue these, but I wanted the option to adjust the size at a later date. The ends of the down supports were cut at an angle to match the brackets and let them fully seat. I attached each leg to the bottom frame of the quad with M3 capscrews and lock nuts. I've attached the 123D file if you wish to adjust. Total weight for the legs and hardware was 102 grams.

description.text:
I have a tubular A-Frame synthesizer/keyboard stand that I purchased in the mid 90's. Previously I've purchases more pipes for it at local industrial metal store, and I wanted more parts to build it out. So I've designed some replacement parts that you can print out and build your own A-Frame keyboard stand.

Update 10/10/2016

Today I just finished making some extra synth support bars. I've added a picture of the bars, and picture of tubing being cut. The bars have a bevelled hole drilled near the center, then a 1//4 inch hole at the front of the bars with a 1/4 inch rolled pin pressed in. I then cover the pressed pin with some 1/4 inch ID tubing, cut just long enough to cover the exposed pin. This tubing protects the synthesizers.

Update 07/29/2016

I've added files that let you build angled connectors.
Improved the Tee connector so that it's much stronger.
I recommend only using Polycarbonate, or ABS Polycarbonate alloy. It's much stronger.

Update

I've made the tee clamp fully customizable using SCAD!! Many parameters that are easy to adjust with comments to hopefully make them easier to understand. Editing this file you can easily make many different types of clamps for many different types of pipes.

Just open the KeyboardRackTee.scad file and edit the variables. Press F6 to view it, then export the STL for printing.

Note: KeyboardRackTee.scad uses BoltMount.scad so Customizer may not work with it.

Here are the parts I have made:

  • small clamp for joints, synthesizer support bars, and support braces
  • tee clamp

Here is what you will need to buy

  • knob (I may be designing one of these soon)
  • screws 1/4" 20 x 1" and 1 1/2"
  • nuts 1/4" 20 thread
  • 1.5" thin walled aluminum pipe
    -- the store I go to has them in different anodized colors
  • 1/4" thick aluminum bar
    -- this makes up the support bar under a keyboard or synthesizer
    -- various lengths based on the depth of the keyboards you are mounting
    -- these are rounded on the front and back so you don't hurt yourself bumping into them
  • 1/4" press pin
    -- this prevents a keyboard from slipping off the support bar
  • 1/4" vacuum cap
    -- this covers up the press pin so it doesn't damage a keyboard

small clamp variations:

  • a single small clamp is the support for a keyboard bar
  • join 2 together to make an angle joint (the top of an A-Frame)
  • join 2 together using an 1/8" thick aluminum bar, approximate 1.5ft length to make a brace between two tubes to prevent wobble. These stands are notorious for wobble, but you can very easily strengthen the stand with a couple of these braces.
  • I've included lots of picture showing the real stand parts and how they are connected.

Update

  • small bracket prints in 1h 37m
  • tee bracket prints in 3h 32m

    OpenSCAD

  • I've switched over to using OpenSCAD instead of SketchUp since it gives me greater control to adapt the clamps to any size pipes. The first test of the OpenSCAD tee clamp is amazing. COMPLETED

    V2

  • Updated inner diameter pipe hole
  • Updated 1/4 20 nut holes to 13.75mm diameter for perfect fit with 1/4" nuts

    Short Clamps Fully Tested

    The short clamps are printing and working fine

This is a compact Bowden extruder for MK8 drive gear and 1.75mm filament. Its constrained filament path allows it to print well with all filaments, including flexibles.

Update 5/13/16 - The file has been modified to accommodate drive gears whose set screws protrude more out from the body of the drive gear.

Hardware:

3 M3 x 20mm Machine Screw
1 M3 x 14mm Machine Screw
2 M3 Hex Nuts
1 3mm x 10mmm x 4mm Bearing (623zz)
2 M3 x 40mm Machine Screw if you use springs on the extruder arm
2 M3 x 25mm Machine Screw if you do not use springs on the extruder arm
1 M6 Hex Nut
1 Bowden Push Fitting with M6 Thread

remixed_from.title: E3D v6 hotend mount for Afinibot / Creality / HURricane 3D printers

title: E3D v6 hotend mount for Afinibot / Creality / HURricane 3D printers REMIX

description.text:
This is a modular mounting adapter for a E3D v6 hotend for the Creality CR7, CR8 / Afinibot / HURricane 3d printers. Which was inspired by SYBU's mount design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1397731)

The mount was designed to be modular, allowing designers to create add-ons for the mount. The add-on bracket included, integrates a cable tie down for the heater, thermistors and fan on the left-hand side of the extruder. To the right of the extruder the bracket will hold an inductive sensor for auto-bed leveling.

I have include the dimensional information for the groove, if you should wish to create a new add-on bracket.

https://youtu.be/XAILH6sUF4s

I plan to update this post at a later date once, I have the printer up and running with the new hot end and firmware updates.

Afinibot

title: Jumper 260+ quad conversion parts, New arms, FPV transmitter holder, Sony CCD camera conversion + misc

description.text:
The new arms are designed to hold the ESC with just friction and a small dab of hot glue (no zip ties needed!) they also have an expected failure point (by design) at the posts to avoid transferring a hard impact onto the mainboard, built in 28mm motor guards. Note: These arms will also work with littlebee 20amp escs as they are the same width as the stock bhheli long 20amp escs with the jumper quad.

FPV transmitter is hot glued in with 1 or two zipties over top to keep it pressed down in the event of a hard crash. Keeps east access to dipswitch to change channel.

The new tilt mount holds the ever so popular sony CCD. Designed it to cradle the board as much as possible since the jumper frame provides 0 protection to the camera. Captures a standard nylon lock nut inside the case to tighten the camera on the pivot points.

Cone legs and antenna brackets are untested but no reason they won't work. Several mounting positions for the cone legs the screw in, you could thread right into the plastic or drill out for brass thread inserts if you prefer.

All of my parts use m3 machine screws and nuts, so you will need to drill out any of the mounting holes used with a 3mm bit or tap it with a 3mm tap to mount these parts.

Note about weight increase, with arms, transmitter bracket, sony ccd plus printed mount and receiver is 405g about 65 grams heavier than the kit with original pieces and no receiver. The 28mm motors with 6" props have 0 issue with that.

Side note about transmitter and camera connections, do yourself a favor and rip those junk ports off the board and replace them with servo leads if you haven't already

description.text:
This character was designed for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for our modular wargaming system, Wayfarer Tactics. If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 166.6%.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

print_settings.Notes:: Print settings don't matter too much... If you print a few of these, each one would only be holding back a tiny bit of weight in even the strongest winds... That said... they're little bits of plastic... don't count on this to hold anything. I'm not responsible if your pet or child pulls out the screen and jumps out of the window.  Come to think of it, I'm not responsible if they pull them out and swallow them... I bear no responsibility here.  At all.  Don't eat these.

description.text:
I replaced a missing screen in my house and it kind of just fell back into the house. I guess the old screens had some spring mechanism built into them to hold them in place. There was a little groove that runs around the entire inside lip of the window frame, so I designed a little retainer clip to hold the screen in place, with a notch on the front side, so it would be easy to remove later if I needed to.

Yes, I need to clean my window... leave me alone.

print_settings.Notes:: I usually make my shells at least 1mm thick, but that's up to you. This is pretty easy to print, really.

description.text:
This is just a modification of the openscad files for the dock this is remixed from.

This was designed to be wide enough for a samsung Galaxy S5 with a relatively thick case; the cable this is intended to be used with is the micro USB one from Snap Power: https://www.snappower.com/snappower-cables/

You can probably find others that are the same dimensions, but I like those cables so that's what I have used. This will probably work for most android phones of roughly the same size or smaller with a micro usb port in the bottom center, but YMMV.

I will be uploading other designs more intended for iphone, though this should work decently for an iphone 6s or 6s plus w/ the snappower lightning cable.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I usually make my shells at least 1mm thick, but that's up to you. This is pretty easy to print, really.
Wicket's Missile from the Playskool Galactic Heroes Endor Playset. (My kid lost it twice while I was modeling it)

title: iPhone 6/6s dock with speaker and mic redirection

description.text:
This will likely work reasonably well for a 6/6s plus as well as a 6/6s.

The cable it's shaped for is the one from https://www.snappower.com/snappower-cables/ -- if you get these then they will fit perfectly, assuming your printer produces the same results as mine (and that always holds true, right? ;-])

This has a reverb box below the speaker and one below the mic both with holes to open to the front; honestly I haven't tested enough yet to decide if these are adequate or need more work, but it's a definite start and I thought I'd publish it so others can look at it.

Obviously, huge thanks to the original designer Okatake who I remixed this from =]

Edit: I updated this with a better speaker reverb chamber, the cable now comes in through the mic chamber (which makes less difference), and there is a second version for deeper cases like the otterbox
